title: CRIC-seq protocol for in situ profiling of proximal RNA-RNA contacts associated with RNA-binding proteins
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell harvest and formaldehyde crosslinking
Timing: ∼1 h
The following steps describe how to harvest adherent cells like HeLa cells for CRIC-seq. Suspension cells can be collected and washed by centrifugation.
Aspirate and discard the medium from the culture dish.
Rinse HeLa cells with 10 mL of pre-chilled 1 × PBS buffer three times.
Fix cells with 10 mL freshly prepared 1% (w/v) formaldehyde solution by shaking the dish on a platform rotator at low speed at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 10 min.
Quench the fixation by adding 500 μL of 2.5 M glycine solution and shaking the dish on an orbital shaker at low speed at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 10 min.
Discard the medium from the dish and rinse cells with 10 mL of pre-chilled 1 × PBS buffer three times.
Scrape off the cells from the culture dish and transfer the cell suspension to a new 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 1,200 g for 10 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant. See troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting], problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Resuspend the cell pellet with 1 mL of pre-chilled 1 × PBS buffer and transfer the cell suspension to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 600 g for 10 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Store the cell pellet at −80°C for up to one month or directly go to the following steps.
Cell permeabilization and micrococcal nuclease treatment
Timing: ∼1.5 h
In this step, cell permeabilization with detergents allows us to “punch holes” in cellular membranes for subsequent enzyme treatment while maintaining the cell intact. Micrococcal nuclease displays both endo- and exonuclease activity to digest free RNA unbound by proteins (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2805-Fig1.jpg

Figure 1. Schematic diagram showing the in situ part of the CRIC-seq method
Permeabilize the cell pellet with 1 mL of permeabilization buffer and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the cell suspension at 4°C for 15 min on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet three times with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.2% NP-40, v/v):
Resuspend the cell pellet with 600 μL of pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.2% NP-40, v/v) and incubate the cell suspension at 4°C for 5 min on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Repeat steps a and b twice.
Dilute the micrococcal nuclease to the final concentration of 0.03 U/μL (Here, we take the micrococcal nuclease from Thermo Fisher, Cat# EN0181, as an example):
Dilute 0.5 μL of micrococcal nuclease with 499.5 μL of 1 × MN buffer (1:1000).
Dilute 50 μL of 1:1000 dilution of micrococcal nuclease with 450 μL of 1 × MN buffer (1:10).
Resuspend the cell pellet from Step 14 with 200 μL of 1:10,000 dilution of micrococcal nuclease and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the cell suspension at 37°C for 10 min in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled 1 × PNK + EGTA buffer as described in Step 14.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.2% NP-40, v/v) as described in Step 14.
pCp-biotin labeling
Timing: ∼18 h

In this step, the 3′ends of fragmented RNAs are labeled with pCp-biotin to mark the junction of proximally ligated RNAs and allow the subsequent enrichment of chimeric RNAs (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Fast AP treatment:
Set up the Fast AP reaction mixture containing 10 μL of 10 × Fast AP buffer, 10 μL of Fast Alkaline Phosphatase, and 80 μL of DEPC-treated H2O for each sample.
Resuspend the cell pellet with the Fast AP reaction mixture and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 37°C for 15 min in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled 1 × PNK + EGTA buffer as described in Step 14.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled High-salt buffer as described in Step 14
Wash the cell pellet three times with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.05% NP-40, v/v) as described in Step 14.
pCp-biotin labeling:
Set up the labeling mixture containing 10 μL of 10 × RNA ligase reaction buffer, 6 μL of Ribolock RNase inhibitor, 4 μL of Biotinylated Cytidine (Bis) phosphate, 10 μL of T4 RNA ligase, and 20 μL of DEPC-treated H2O for each sample.
Note: For PTBP1 IP (−pCp) libraries, exclude the Biotinylated Cytidine (Bis) phosphate.
Resuspend the cell pellet with the labeling mixture and mix well by gently pipetting.
Add 50 μL of 30% (w/v) PEG 20000 to the cell suspension and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 16°C overnight (12–16 h) in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.

Note: Cut off the pipette tip before aspirating the 30% (w/v) PEG 20000, and do not vortex when homogenizing the suspension.
Add 4 μL of 10 mM ATP and 2 μL of T4 RNA ligase to the sample and mix well by gently pipetting up and down on the next day.
Incubate the sample at 16°C for another 3 h in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Centrifuge the sample at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet three times with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.2% NP-40, v/v) as described in Step 14.
Proximity ligation
Timing: ∼19 h
In this step, protein-mediated proximal RNA-RNA contacts are ligated (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Fast AP treatment:
Set up the Fast AP mixture containing 10 μL of 10 × Fast AP buffer, 10 μL of Fast Alkaline Phosphatase, and 80 μL of DEPC-treated H2O for each sample.
Resuspend the cell pellet with the Fast AP mixture and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 37°C for 15 min in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled 1 × PNK + EGTA buffer as described in Step 14.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled High-salt buffer as described in Step 14
Wash the cell pellet three times with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.2% NP-40, v/v) as described in Step 14.
PNK treatment:

Set up the PNK mixture containing 10 μL of 10 × reaction buffer A, 10 μL of T4 Polynucleotide Kinase, 15 μL of 10 mM ATP, and 65 μL of DEPC-treated H2O for each sample.
Resuspend the cell pellet with the PNK mixture and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 37°C for 45 min in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Wash the cell pellet twice with pre-chilled 1 × PNK + EGTA buffer as described in Step 14.
Wash the cell pellet three times with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.05% NP-40, v/v) as described in Step 14.
Proximal RNA ligation:
Set up the ligation mixture containing 20 μL of 10 × RNA ligase reaction buffer, 8 μL of Ribolock RNase inhibitor, 20 μL of 1 mg/mL BSA, 10 μL of T4 RNA ligase, and 142 μL of DEPC-treated H2O for each sample.
Resuspend the cell pellet with the ligation mixture and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 16°C overnight (12–16 h) in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
On the next day, add 4 μL of 10 mM ATP and 2 μL of T4 RNA ligase to the sample and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 16°C for another 3 h in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Centrifuge the sample at 1,200 g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the cell pellet three times with pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.2% NP-40, v/v) as described in Step 14.
Protein-RNA enrichment
Timing: ∼7 h

In this step, the complex of PTBP1 and its associated RNA-RNA contacts is immunoprecipitated with a PTBP1-specific antibody.
Beads preparation:
Prepare 50 μL of protein A/G magnetic beads per sample. Expel the beads into a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube and place it on a magnetic rack for 1 min.
Discard the supernatant and rinse the beads three times with 500 μL of 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer (pH 8.0) containing 0.05% Tween 20 by gently pipetting up and down.
Resuspend beads with 150 μL 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer (pH 8.0, 0.05% Tween20) containing 15 μg PTBP1-specific antibody.
Note: Ensure that the volume of 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer (pH 8.0) is triple the volume of the antibody. For IgG IP (+pCp) libraries, use IgG-specific antibodies.
Incubate the beads with PTBP1 antibody at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 1 h on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
Wash beads three times with 500 μL of pre-chilled wash buffer by gently pipetting up and down.
Note: To prevent over-drying the beads, prepare the cell lysis as described in Step 41 during the incubation in “d” and directly resuspend the PTBP1 antibody-coupled beads with the cell lysate after washing beads.
Cell lysis and immunoprecipitation:
Resuspend the cell pellet from Step 39 with 500 μL of wash buffer and sonicate on ice with BRANSON SLPe at 40% amplitude for 10 s on/ 30 s off for 3 cycles. See troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting], problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Incubate the cell suspension at 4°C for 15 min on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 15 min at 4°C and collect the supernatant into a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.

Resuspend the PTBP1 antibody-coupled beads from Step 40 with the cell lysate and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 4°C for 4 h on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
Wash beads three times with 500 μL of pre-chilled wash buffer by gently pipetting up and down.
Wash beads once with 500 μL of pre-chilled High-salt wash buffer II by gently pipetting up and down.
Wash beads twice with 500 μL of pre-chilled 1 × PNK buffer (0.5% NP-40, v/v) by gently pipetting up and down.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
RNA purification
Timing: ∼15 h
In this step, RNA-RNA contacts associated with PTBP1 are isolated from the protein-RNA complexes.
Resuspend the beads from Step 45 with 200 μL of proteinase K buffer and 50 μL of proteinase K and mix well by gently pipetting.
Incubate the sample at 37°C for 60 min, and then 56°C for 15 min in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Add 750 μL of Trizol LS to the supernatant, homogenize it by pipetting up and down 20 times, and incubate the sample at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 5 min.
Add 220 μL of chloroform to the sample, mix well by shaking vigorously for 15 s, and incubate at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 3 min.
Centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 15 min at 4°C and carefully pipette the aqueous phase to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.

Add 1 μL of GlycoBlue and 500 μL of isopropanol to the sample and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Precipitate the RNA at −20°C overnight (12–16 h).
Centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 15 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the RNA pellet twice with 600 μL of 75% (v/v) ethanol and centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant thoroughly and air-dry the pellet for 2 min.
Note: Do not over-dry the RNA.
Dissolve the pellet in 15 μL of DEPC-treated water.
Pause point: The RNA sample can be stored at −80°C for several weeks.
pCp-biotin selection
Timing: ∼16 h
In this step, chimeric RNAs are selected with streptavidin beads through biotinylated cytidine at the junction of ligated RNA fragments.
Blocking beads:
Vortex the Dynabeads MyOne Streptavidin C1 beads in the vial for at least 30 s and transfer 20 μL of beads per sample to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the beads with an equal volume of solution A and mix well by gently pipetting up and down.
Incubate the beads at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 2 min, place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min, and discard the supernatant.
Repeat Steps a-d once.
Wash the beads with an equal volume of solution B by gently pipetting up and down.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the beads with 200 μL of the blocking mixture containing 50 μg of yeast RNA and 100 μL of 2 × TWB buffer. Mix well by gently pipetting up and down.

Incubate the beads at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 1 h on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Note: To save time, perform Steps 59 and 60 during this 1-h incubation.
Wash the beads three times with 600 μL of 1 × TWB buffer by gently pipetting up and down.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
DNase I treatment:
Set up the DNase I mixture containing 15 μL of RNA from Step 57, 10 μL of 10 × RQ1 DNase I buffer, 3 μL of RiboLock RNase Inhibitor, 5 μL of DNase I, and 67 μL of DEPC-treated H2O.
Incubate the DNase I mixture at 37°C for 20 min in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 1,000 rpm every 3 min.
Purified RNA with ZYMO RESEARCH RNA Clean and Concentrator-5 according to the manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_r1013_r1014_r1015_r1016_rna_clean_concentrator-5.pdf]. Elute the RNA with 17.5 μL DEPC-treated water and transfer the 16 μL of eluted RNA to a new 200 μL PCR tube.
Pause point: The resultant RNA can be stored at −80°C for several weeks.
RNA fragmentation:
Add 4 μL of 5 × first-strand buffer to the RNA and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at 94°C for 5 min and put it on ice immediately.
Biotin-streptavidin selection:
Add the 20 μL of fragmented RNA, 30 μL of DEPC-treated water, and 50 μL of 2 × TWB buffer to the beads from Step 58.
Incubate the beads at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 0.5 h on a tube rotator at 20 rpm.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
Wash the beads four times with 600 μL of 1 × TWB buffer by gently pipetting up and down.

Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and thoroughly discard the supernatant.
RNA elution:
Resuspend the beads with 100 μL of PK buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at 95°C for 10 min at 1000 rpm in a ThermoMixer.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Repeat Steps a and b once. Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and transfer the supernatant to the same 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube from Step c.
Resuspend the beads with 100 μL of PK buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min and transfer the supernatant to the same 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube from Step c.
Add 300 μL of Acid Phenol: Chloroform to the 300 μL of sample and mix well by shaking vigorously.
Centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 10 min at 4°C and transfer the aqueous phase carefully to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Add 18 μL of 5 M NaCl, 1 μL of GlycoBlue, and 900 μL of 100% (v/v) ethanol to the sample sequentially. Mix well by pipetting up and down.
Precipitate the RNA at −20°C overnight (12–16 h).
On the next day, centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 20 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Wash the RNA pellet twice with 600 μL of 75% (v/v) ethanol and centrifuge the sample at 16,000 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant thoroughly and air-dry the pellet for 2 min.
Note: Do not over-dry the RNA.
Dissolve the RNA pellet in 10 μL of DEPC-treated water.

Pause point: The resultant RNA can be stored at −80°C for several weeks.
Strand-specific library construction
Timing: ∼9 h
In this step, RNAs enriched by PTBP1 antibody and streptavidin beads are converted into a strand-specific library with defined adapters for paired-end deep sequencing.
First-strand synthesis:
Transfer the RNA solution from Step 70 to a new 200 μL PCR tube, add 0.5 μL of 100 ng/μL N6 primer to the solution and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at 65°C for 5 min in a thermal cycler, and immediately put it on ice for at least 2 min.
Set up the reaction mixture containing 3 μL of 5 × first-strand buffer, 0.5 μL of Ribolock RNase inhibitor, 1 μL of 10 mM dNTPs, 0.5 μL of 0.1 M DDT, and 0.5 μL of SuperScript II Reverse Transcriptase.
Add the reaction mixture to the RNA sample from Step b and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at 25°C for 10 min, 42°C for 40 min, and 70°C for 15 min in a thermal cycler.
Transfer the sample to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Second-strand synthesis:
Set up the second-strand mixture containing 10 μL of 5 × second-strand buffer, 0.8 μL of 25 mM dNTPs (dUTP), 0.2 μL of RNase H, 2.5 μL of E. Coli DNA Polymerase I and 20.5 μL of DEPC-treated H2O and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Add the second-strand mixture to the 16 μL sample from Step 71 and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at 16°C for 2 h in a ThermoMixer programmed with 15 s of intermittent mixing at 300 rpm every 3 min.

Note: During the incubation, take out the AMPure XP beads from 4°C and equilibrate the beads for 30 min at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Vortex the AMPure XP beads for 30 s, aspirate 90 μL of beads to the sample from Step 72 and mix well by pipetting.
Incubate the sample at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 5 min, and then place the tube on a magnetic rack.
Discard the supernatant when the solution is clear from the beads.
Wash the beads with 200 μL of freshly prepared 80% (v/v) ethanol twice by spinning the tube on the magnetic rack.
Thoroughly discard the ethanol and let the beads dry in the air.
Resuspend the beads with 44 μL of Qiagen Elution Buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 5 min, and then place the tube on a magnetic rack.
Transfer the 43 μL supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube. Quantify the concentration of the cDNA with 1 μL of the sample with Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit according to the manufacturer’s instruction[href=https://www.thermofisher.cn/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FQubit_dsDNA_HS_Assay_UG.pdf].
Note: The expected yield is about 0.1–0.3 ng/μL.
End repair:
Set up the end repair mixture containing 42 μL of cDNA from Step 80, 0.4 μL of 25 mM dNTPs, 1.2 μL of T4 DNA polymerase, 0.2 μL of Klenow Fragment, 1.2 μL of T4 Polynucleotide Kinase and 5 μL of 10 × Polynucleotide Kinase buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at 20°C for 30 min in a ThermoMixer.
Purify the sample with 90 μL of AMPure XP beads as described in Steps 73–77.
Resuspend the beads with 20.5 μL of Qiagen Elution Buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.

Incubate the sample at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 5 min, and then place the tube on a magnetic rack.
Transfer the 19.7 μL supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
dA-tailing:
Set up the dA-tailing mixture containing 19.7 μL of the sample, 2.3 μL of 10 × Blue buffer, 0.5 μL of 5 mM dATP, and 0.5 μL of Klenow (3′ to 5′ exo-).
Incubate the sample at 37°C for 30 min in a ThermoMixer.
Adapter ligation:
Set up the adapter mixture containing 1.4 μL of 2 × rapid ligation buffer, 0.1 μL of 10 mM ATP, and 1 μL of 2 μM adapter.
Add the adapter mixture to 23 μL of the sample from Step 82 and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Add 1 μL of T4 quick DNA ligase to the mixture from the last step and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Note: Adding T4 quick DNA ligase last can prevent potential adapter-adapter ligation.
Incubate the sample at 20°C for 15 min in a ThermoMixer.
Purify the sample with 47.7 μL of AMPure XP beads as described in Steps 73–77.
Resuspend the beads with 25 μL of Qiagen Elution Buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 5 min, and then place the tube on a magnetic rack.
Transfer the 25 μL of supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf LoBind tube.
Purify the sample with 45 μL of AMPure XP beads as described in Steps 73–77.
Resuspend the beads with 18.5 μL of Qiagen Elution Buffer and mix well by pipetting up and down.
Incubate the sample at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 5 min, and then place the tube on a magnetic rack.

Transfer the 17.7 μL of supernatant to a new 200 μL PCR tube.
Pause point: The resultant DNA can be stored at −20°C for up to 1 month.
Test optimal PCR cycle numbers:
Take 1 μL of the sample from Step 91 as a template and set up the PCR reaction master mix as follows:

Perform the PCR amplification using the PCR cycling conditions:

Note: Pretreatment at 37°C allows the digestion of dUTP-containing strand by USER enzyme. Typically test two different PCR cycle numbers for PTBP1 IP (+pCp) samples but not PTBP1 IP (−pCp) and IgG IP (+pCp) samples.
Determine the amount of PCR products by running the samples in 1.5% agarose gel in 1 × TBE at 120 V for ∼1 h and examine the DNA bands with blue-light transilluminator. See troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] for problems 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
PCR with optimal PCR cycle number:
Set up the PCR reaction master mix as follows:

Note: Use different index primers for different samples. Amplifying all the samples with the same cycle numbers.
Perform the PCR amplification using the PCR cycling conditions:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2805_17.csv
Critical: Excessive PCR amplification will increase the duplicate rate and decrease the complexity of libraries.
Run the samples in 1.5% agarose gel in 1 × TBE at 120 V for ∼1 h and examine the DNA bands with blue-light transilluminator.
Note: Avoid using the UV transilluminator to prevent DNA damage.
Cut the smeared DNA bands between 200–450 bp from the agarose gel.
Purify the DNA with a Qiagen MinElute Gel Extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s instruction[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=0d0d73a7-e906-4a74-8f11-3b70311d7d66&lang=en] and elute with 15 μL of Elution Buffer.
Quantify the concentration of the DNA with 1 μL of the sample with Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit according to the manufacturer’s instruction[href=https://www.thermofisher.cn/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2FQubit_dsDNA_HS_Assay_UG.pdf].

Detect DNA length distribution of libraries with Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer according to the manufacturer’s instruction[href=https://mhir.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/G2938-90321_SensitivityDNA_KG_EN-1.pdf].
Note: The libraries can be stored at −20°C for 6 months or directly sequenced with the Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform using paired-end mode.
Deep sequencing and data processing
Timing: ∼12 days
In this step, strand-specific CRIC-seq libraries are sequenced with the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 platform in paired-end mode.
The RBP IP (+pCp) CRIC-seq libraries typically require ∼200 million raw reads per sample, whereas the equal volume of IgG IP (+pCp) and RBP IP (−pCp) CRIC-seq libraries only can produce ∼0.15 million raw reads per sample in our hands.
Process the CRIC-seq paired-end raw reads in FASTQ files using the RICpipe program (https://github.com/caochch/RICpipe[href=https://github.com/caochch/RICpipe])8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] to obtain intra- and inter-molecular chimeric reads in sam files. See troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] for problems 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Trim the adapters using the Trimmomatic software and remove PCR duplicates with identical sequences, but keep only one read.
Align the remaining reads sequentially to the human genome using the STAR and BWA softwares to identify chimeric reads that are chiastically mapped.
Classify the chimeric reads as intra-molecular if both arms are mapped to the same transcript while classifying those with two arms mapped to different transcripts as inter-molecular.
Remove the intra-molecular chimeric reads that are mapped to splicing junctions.
Combine the two replicates for downstream analysis if they exhibit a high correlation of chimeric reads per transcript.

Note: A high percentage of PCR duplicates in a sequencing dataset can indicate poor sequencing quality or unsuccessful library construction. The low percentage of PCR duplicates (∼20%) in the case of PTBP1 CRIC-seq libraries suggests that the library construction was successful. Chimeric ratio measurement is another parameter to assess library quality. For the PTBP1 CRIC-seq library, we observed a chimeric read ratio of approximately 7%, with 90% of the chimeric reads being intra-molecular, consistent with our expectations. Additionally, we evaluated the reproducibility of the CRIC-seq library across biological replicates by calculating their Pearson correlation coefficient. The correlation coefficient was greater than 0.9, indicating high reproducibility between the replicates.
Identify background contacts during CRIC-seq library construction:
Merge the chimeric reads from IgG IP (+pCp) and RBP IP (−pCp) and save them as a SAM format file named “background_Chimeric.sam”.
Extract the coordinates of the pairwise junction sites for the background chimeric reads and save them to a BEDPE format file named “background_Chimeric_junction.bedpair”.
Cluster the chimeric reads in the background group if their junction sites are in a pairwise 10-nt genomic window.
>cat IgG_(+pCp)_CRIC_Chimeric.sam RBP_(-pCp)_CRIC_Chimeric.sam > background_Chimeric.sam
>perl from_sam_to_bedOfJunctionPair.pl background_Chimeric.sam > background_Chimeric_junction.bedpair
>perl merge_IgG_pCp_minus_to_background.pl background_Chimeric_junction.bedpair
Calculate the chimeric read counts for RBP IP (+pCp) and background CRIC-seq:
Extract the coordinates of pairwise junction sites from RBP IP (+pCp) CRIC-seq chimeric reads and store them in a BEDPE format file named "RBP_(+pCp)_Chimeric_junction.bedpair".
Collect the read counts for RBP IP (+pCp) CRIC-seq chimeric reads and background chimeric reads residing in background clusters and save them as files named "RBP_(+pCp)_Chimeric.in_background_cluster.list" and "background_Chimeric.in_background_cluster.list".
> perl from_sam_to_bedOfJunctionPair.pl RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_Chimeric.sam > RBP_(+pCp)_Chimeric_junction.bedpair
>bedtools pairtopair -a background.raw_cluster.bed -b RBP_(+pCp)_Chimeric_junction.bedpair -is -rdn > RBP_(+pCp)_Chimeric.in_background_cluster.list
>bedtools pairtopair -a background.raw_cluster.bed -b background_Chimeric_junction.bedpair -is -rdn > background_ Chimeric.in_ background_cluster.list
Remove background from RBP IP (+pCp) CRIC-seq libraries:

Identify RBP IP (+pCp) CRIC-seq chimeric reads with read counts that are at least 5 times higher than the background chimeric read counts obtained in step 97, and extract them.
Save the extracted chimeric reads as a SAM format file named "RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.sam" in the output directory.
> python remove_background_from_RBP_IP_chimeric_reads.py background.raw_cluster.bed background_Chimeric.in_background_cluster.list RBP_(+pCp)_Chimeric.in_background_cluster.list RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_Chimeric.sam
Note: To determine the fold change item in “a”, we have tested different values ranging from 1 to 100 for the removal of background chimeric reads. We found that a 5-fold change is an optimal threshold, as it effectively removes the background chimeric reads while preserving more of the RBP IP CRIC-seq chimeric reads. This parameter is independent of RNA expression and can be customized to suit the user's project requirements.
Identify the high-confidence clusters:
Extract the pairwise junction site coordinates from the RBP IP (+pCp) CRIC-seq chimeric reads from step 98 and save them to a BEDPE file named "RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.list".
Cluster the junction sites that are located within the same pairwise 10-nt genomic windows, and save the clustered sites to a file named "RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.cluster".
> perl from_sam_to_listOfJunctionPair.pl RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.sam > RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.list
>less RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.list | sort -k3,3 -k8,8 > RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.sort.list
> perl cluster_RBP_IP_chimeric_reads.pl RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.sort.list > RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.cluster
Note: The determination of window sizes in “b” did not involve the use of statistical methods but is based on laboratory experience and published articles.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],15[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15] We found that a window size of 10 nucleotides provides high nucleotide resolution for RNA-RNA contact information. This parameter can be customized to meet the specific requirements of individual projects.
Select clusters that are supported by at least 2 chimeric reads.
Save the genome coordinates of these clusters as a BEDPE file named "removed_background_RBP_merged.Chimeric.cluster.2.bedpair".
> python make_RBP_IP_cluster_bedpair.py RBP_(+pCp)_CRIC_removed_background_Chimeric.cluster read_count_cutoff

Note: To identify a cluster assembly, we set a minimum requirement of two chimeric reads and did not try a more stringent cutoff for the number of chimeric reads. The threshold for the number of chimeric reads can be customized by the user according to their requirements.
Predict the structure of U1 snRNAs:
Assemble U1 (NR_004430.2) sequences into a mini-genome.
Map sequencing reads to the U1 mini-genome using the RICpipe program.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
Visualize the resulting chimeric reads mapped to U1 in the BAM format file using the Integrative Genomics Viewer (IGV) tool.
> samtools view -bS -o U1_chimeric_reads.bam U1_chimeric_reads.sam
> samtools sort -o U1_chimeric_reads.sort.bam U1_chimeric_reads.bam
> samtools index U1_chimeric_reads.sort.bam
Note: RNA-RNA interactions can sometimes lead to RNA duplex formation. Combining the RNA proximity information provided by CRIC-seq with RNA structure prediction software can model those RNA duplexes. Here, we took U1 snRNA as an example.
Detect the distribution of the PTBP1 binding motif in chimeric reads with the FIMO package from MEME suites14[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]:
Randomly shuffle the locations of chimeric reads of the same size to establish control.
Calculate the average motif density in 100 windows around ± 1 kb of chimeric reads.
> fastaFromBed -fi human_reference_genome.fa -fo chimeric_reads.fa -bed chimeric_reads.bed -name+ -s
> fasta-get-markov chimeric.reads.fa chimeric_reads.markov.b -norc -m 1
> fimo -no-qvalue --norc --thresh 0.01 --motif-pseudo 0.1 --max-stored-scores 100000000 --bgfile chimeric_reads.markov.b --oc ./output PTBP1_binding_motif_pwms.txt chimeric_reads.fa
> bedtools shuffle -i chimeric_reads.bed -g human_reference_genome_size.txt -excl chimeric_reads.bed > chimeric_reads_shuffled.bed
Note: The position weight matrix of the PTBP1 binding motif, named "PTBP1_binding_motif_pwms.txt", is generated using the uniprobe2meme package of the MEME suite.14[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]
